er's house a few doors off—a little girl was standing at the door and Mrs. Payne told me to go upstairs—I did so, and found the child lying on the bed in a very deplorable condition—I recognised it chiefly by its dark eyes—it was moaning and crying with its mouth wide open—it was very dirty, its frock and pinafore were miserable—I only saw its clothes then—it was a perfect skeleton, and nothing like the child I had seen six weeks before—I went home and spoke to my husband, and next day, about 2.30 in the afternoon, he went with me to the prisoner's house—we went unexpectedly—the prisoner was out, we saw the little girl—we went upstairs and found the child in the same state, worse, if anything—its body was very dirty—it was covered over with an old black shaw l—it was making no noise that day; it was very quiet—I sent for something for it—its mouth was very sore—I asked for the baby's bottle, which was given to me in a very dirty state in
deed—I sent it down to Mrs. Payne to wash it, and asked for some warm water—I then gave the baby the milk from the bottle, which it took very ravenously—it had no diapers on, and its clothes were very much soiled—its flesh was very much wrinkled—we then went to the Islington Work-house and saw the matron and afterwards the relieving officer, who went with us back to the prisoner's house—we found her there—I had told the little girl that we should go for a policeman—the baby had then been changed into clean clothes and the prisoner was feeding it with brandy and egg—I told her I was very shocked to find the child in that way, and it was very unkind of her to treat it so badly and in that dirty neglected state—she said that she had not neglected it—she had left it with her little girl to look after it—the relieving officer went with me and we took it to the union and left it with the night nurse—I had never seen a child in such a state before—it was very scantily clothed—I touched it, it was cold; it had no socks on and nothing to keep it warm.

Cross-examined. My husband was an earthenware dealer—I have seven children and have considerable experience in the care of young children—when I took the child to the prisoner I did not say that it was for six weeks—I said that it had no socks, and that its feet were cold, but its feet were covered over—I am not in the habit of paying visits to very poor people this was the 26th of August—it was remarkably fine weather—I should load clothes on a sick child at that time of year—I have had a child of mine suffering from diarrhoea, and I lost one nine months old—I do not think it was ill twenty-four hours—when I left on the second occasion to go to the workhouse, I did not tell the prisoner when I should return—I had given no suggestion or directions and yet I found her when I returned feeding it with egg and brandy—the girl was fifteen years old—there is nothing remarkable in a girl of that age attending to a baby—when the child was first left with the prisoner I paid for some milk and for a bottle, out of my own pocket.

CHARLOTTE PAYNE . I am the wife of Frederick Payne, a shoemaker, of 89, Andrew Street, Holloway, in the same house with the prisoner—we occupy the ground floor, and have lived there about two years and a half—

she has been taking in children to nurse on and off all that time—some were left there by the day, some by the hour for a few hours together, and some altogether—I remember the child Onslow coming there—I saw it; it was a very nice baby—the prisoner was sometimes out all day, and some
times she was in and out—at times I hardly know whether she was in or out—a little girl of 10 or 11 used to have charge of the child, but she does not look so old—she sometimes minded the children, but she was downstairs the best part of the time when her mother was out—I never saw the baby out but twice, and that was when the prisoner took it to a doctor—I used to hear it cry nearly all day—I have had it downstairs two or three times, and I washed it once, but I only went upstairs to see it when the lady asked me to wash the bottle—it was very dirty indeed when I washed it—I fed it on two occasions, and it took the food as if it would choke itself—after it had been there some weeks it looked as if it was dying—I gave it nursery biscuits, which I bought for my own children—one evening, when I went to bolt the back door, I heard the prisoner say "Put a little drop of water in the bottle and a bit of sugar, and that will do for Willie to-night"—I do not know who she spoke to—Willie was the baby which is dead—the children used to call him Willie—I have never seen any food provided for the child; no milk was taken in at the door—the children used to fetch a pennyworth, and that was all I ever saw—Mrs. Johnson had five children and this baby made six, and a pennyworth of milk was all they had during the day—the children passed through the passage and my children were at the door, and they used to say "Who is that milk for? and the answer was "Willie"—I told the prisoner the baby looked bad, and said "Are you going to take it to the doctor's?"—she said "I have taken it to the doctor, and it is getting all right"—I said "It does look a deplorable little crea
ture"—I have said to her that it was a shame to go away and leave the child crying like that, and she went upstairs—when Mrs. Barales came she sent for some water to wash the bottle, and of course I took it up and saw the child—it was lying on the bed with another child belonging to Mrs. Langridge—the gentleman gave the child the bottle, and it took it as if it was going down a sink almost—I used to hear the child all the week it was there, night and day—it used to make my heart ache to hear it cry, being the mother of eight children—I heard crying and moaning too—when I went up into the room I saw that it was in a neglected state—it was afterwards taken to the workhouse, and the lady and her husband came back again about 5 or 6 o'clock—I did not think the child would live till it got to the workhouse—the gentleman offered me a sovereign to take it there and then—the prisoner has no husband; she goes out nursing people, and did so during the time the child was there—she would never let any
body know her business—she has sometimes had three or four children there—she got her living, as far as I know, by going out nursing and taking in children.

Cross-examined. I remember her coming to the house, and her husband; be died there—I never had any altercation with the prisoner—I used to go up and take her husband fruit, and never had any dispute with her, only just a few words to her children—I am not in the habit of going into her room—I saw nothing of her passing up and down—I believe the child had diarrhoea, and was taken to Dr. Coffin's, dispensary twice—I heard the pri
soner say to her daughter "Take it Coffin's"—she took it to the sister Mrs. Smith, I believe, first, and she was so frightened that she said "Let us

take it to a doctor—I do not think I have heard her express any anxiety that the child should recover—I believe she showed a disposition to neglect it—she might have gone to the doctor many times without my knowing it—there was never more than ld. worth of milk brought into the house in a day for the six children; whether the others had any I cannot say—I never saw any preserved milk in the house and never heard of any coming in—I have not seen empty tins about—I pay as much as 5s. 6d. a week for it my self—it is not unusual to feed children on condensed milk I give them biscuit as well—condensed milk does not come into the house in the same way as other milk, it comes in quietly—when the child has been crying I have told the children when they were playing to go up to the baby and they have gone up—I heard the girl of fifteen say to her mother once when she was coming downstairs "I'm not going to look after the child"—I never sent the girl to the pawnshop, she went of her own accord to take a thimble because she wanted bread—I do not know when that was, but she came home and said "Oh, Mrs. Payne, they have kept my thimble, I wanted to take it because I wanted some bread"—she asked me to get the thimble back—I had no altercation with the prisoner about it—the other child which was with Willie was going the same way, but it is now going on well it gained 1/4 1b. of flesh in nine days.

By THE COURT. Condensed milk is 7 1/2 d. a tin, the best, but you can get it 4 1/2 d.—I should give a tin to one of my children at twice—besides the prisoner and her five children and the baby who is dead, there was a man lodger—there were two children four years old; there were five there, and there was another child who did not come home—sometimes three or four children were taken there to nurse in the day time—Emma Langridge's child was between sis and seven months old—I have seen her pay 8d. or 9d. for the" day, and I have seen her give the children a penny and twopence to get some biscuits—she used to pay every night when she fetched the baby, it was only there in the day time—the prisoner's children were nice, healthy-looking, fine children, in fact they are finer children than my own—one of them has gone out two or three times to earn something—I saw the children a very few minutes—except at the time they were at school they always seemed to be very well and well nourished—I should give a baby of that age a pint or a pint and a half of milk a day and a nursery bis
cuit, which you get twenty four of for 6 1/2 d.—I give my children one biscuit at night and one in the morning and then they would last a week for the 6 1/2 d.—Ialso give different little things—milk is 3 d. a pint in that neigh
bourbood and 4 1/2 d. a day would provide the very best—it would cost 3s. or 3s. 6d. a week to keep the baby—I think 5s. a week would cover the expense for a baby like that, without luxuries—once whenl I was over at the chandler's—shop 1 saw the baby at the window and I said "Oh, I say, that baby does look bad!"—I never saw brandy and egg given to a baby before—when my children are ill I have given them a drop of brandy in the milk if they have been troubled with wind—the prisoner's rent was 5s. 6d. a week—I do not know what the man lodger paid.

EMMA LANGRIDGE . I am a charwoman, and live at 47, Durham Road, Holloway—I have a child about six months old; the prisoner used to take charge of it during the day—I first sent it to her about thirteen weeks ago and she had it to mind for eleven weeks during the day—I used to fetch it away at night and take it back to her in the morning—I paid her 8d. a day, but if I was late I paid her 9d. or 10d.—the usual hours were from 8 to 9

o'clock—she paid for the food—the payment was 6d. a day for minding it and 2d. for biscuits—I used to give her the milk—I fed the child at my breast in the night—I used to see the child William Onslow, it was a very healthy, nice-looking child, indeed, when it was first brought, but there was a wonderful change in it two or three weeks after it had been there—I saw it every day—it was on the bed—I never saw it nursed but once when it was brought down to Mrs. Payne's room, that is the only time I have seen it in anybody's firms except my own—I said to the prisoner "How thin the baby is getting"—she said "It has diarrhoea"—she also said that it had got the mother's complaint; I do not know what that was, but I said "The mother is a very strong woman"—the child got better from the diarrhoea, but it gradually got thin till it was taken away—it was very thin then—I have seen it fed with treacle and bread, sopped, in a jar which looked very nasty and dirty, and the jar did not look clean, there was dried sop all over it—one Saturday night I was very late and the prisoner said "You never left me any arrowroot, never mind, a little water and sugar will do for to-night," and she put it in the bottle and sent the girl in with it for the baby—I removed my child from the prisoner, it was gradually growing thinner.

Cross-examined. I never heard of the deceased child being taken to a medical man—I have two children—I never saw my own child fed on bread and treacle and never heard of bread and treacle being given—when I saw the deceased child getting ill I got very anxious about my own and got somebody else to mind it—the deceased got gradually thinner and would not take any notice; it got very dull indeed.

HANNAH SMITH . I am the wife of John Smith—we have no children; Eliza Onslow is my sister—on 16th July, she came to me with Mrs.—Barales and the child—I declined to take it, but sent for the pri
soner who came and engaged to take it, and I supplied it with clothes—I saw it a fortnight afterwards, it was very ill with diarrhoea and got very thin—it got better, but still continued thin—I suggested taking it to Dr. Coffin, and the prisoner went there with me once—he ordered it cow's milk instead of condensed milk—I do not whether it had had condensed milk before; the prisoner took it to Dr. Coffin by herself the second time, but she brought it to me both going and coming back—when. it was ill I took it some beef tea; the prisoner said its mouth was so bad that she did not know what she could do for it—it got very ill, and she did not expect it would live the night through, and she promised to send for me, but it got better—it was a fine child when it was taken to her—I afterwards saw Mrs. Barales at the house—the child was then wonderfully altered; I had not seen him for a fortnight—he had got very thin and ill—he was not smartly dressed, but was in my own opinion dirty—I saw a bottle with milk in it lying by its side when I went i, Mrs. Barales was there then.

Cross-examined. MR. COFFIN gave the prisoner some medicine for the child's mouth—it was treated for its mouth as well as for diarrhoea—I had no reason to believe it was neglected—the prisoner was always at home when I went—I attributed its getting thin to the diarrhoea—there was nothing to lead me to suspect that it was neglected—I called sometimes once and sometimes twice, and when it was ill I was there three times—the prisoner said that she gave it baked flour and condensed milk and sweet biscuits, and said that it always ate very well.
HENRY THOMAS MAYNARD . I am relieving officer for Upper Holloway—on 28th May Mr. and Mrs. Barales applied to me and I went with them to
the prisoner's house and saw a child in an upstairs room in a very weak and low condition—I gave orders for its removal to the workhouse and it was taken away in a cab.
Cross-examined. I have known the prisoner some time—I always found her very decent and cleanly.

BRIDGET COSGROVE . I am a nurse at the Islington Workhouse—the deceased child was brought there on the 16th of July—to all appearances it was a very healthy child—it was brought to the workhouse again on 28th August, and I think I saw it on the 29th—I could not recognise it then, it was in a dying condition and was sent to the infirmary—I did not attend it afterwards—I only had charge of it as wet nurse—it had been in my care from the 14th of May to the 16th of July, when the mother went out as wet nurse.

ELIZA JUDGE . I am superintendent night nurse at Islington Workhouse—I saw the deceased on 28th August; it was so weak that it could not take the breast, but after carefully feeding it for two hours it was able to do so, but very feebly—I fed it with beef tea and arrowroot and milk for two hours and warmed it, and then it was able to take the breast—it went on pretty well to the Friday and then began to sink, and it died on Satur
day morning the 2nd of September—I never heard it cry, it was too feeble—it was very thin and emaciated—it had no diarrhoea then.

PHILLIP COWEN , M. R. C. S. I am resident medical officer for the Islington Workhouse—I attended Eliza Onslow in her confinement, and on 28th August the child was brought to me by Mrs. Barales in a very emaciated condition—I ordered it to be taken up to a suckling woman, and also to have some beef tea and arrowroot—I did not expect it would recover, it had the ordinary signs of emaciation; wrinkled skin, prominent cheek bones, and sunken eyes—there was no apparent disease—it was then clean and there were no signs in the flexes of the thighs and such parts as though it had been neglected—there were no sores from non-washing and drying, but there was a little external redness of the anus, which indicated that there had been diarrhcea—I was told by the day-nurse that it had had diarrhoea for two days after its admission; that nurse is not here—I spoke to Eliza Judge about it; nothing was said about diarrhcea—I afterwards made a post-mortem examination—there were no marks of violence externally; the whole of the organs were healthy, except two, although they were deficient in blood—the brain was healthy, but between the skull and the dura mater—there were 3 ounces of serum; the mesenteric glands were somewbat degenerated—the middle part of the intestine was empty, the large intestine contained fair-looking fcecal matter; I say fair, in a healthy sense—the other organs were all healthy—the enlargement and degenera
tion of the mesenteric glauds is sometimes constitutional, and is pro
duced by bringing children up by hand—the state of the mesenteric glands was not sufficient to account for death—the cause of death was mesenteric disease and emaciation, and the question is how that emaciation was produced—there was serum in the brain, but there was no disease to account for that; that is a symptom when the current of blood from some debilitating cause becomes more slow, and the capilaries give out serum—that is common in exhausting maladies, in children especially—that is common whenever the condition is debilitated, from whatever cause—the condition of the mesenteric glands and of the brain, was not sufficient to account for death—there was no disease of the brain to account for death—

I have heard the whole of the evidence—the emaciation might be produced from neglect or from diarrhoea—diarrboea would produce almost the same symptoms as neglect—the emaciation is almost in appearance the same as it would be from severe diarrhoea—there was nothing on the post-mortem examination which enables me to say whether the emaciation was caused by the one or the other.
NOT GUILTY .

737.
ANN JOHNSON (38), was again indicted
for unlawfully neglecting to attend to a child of which she had voluntarily taken charge, and causing its life to be endangered.
NOT GUILTY .

738.
SAMUEL WILLIAM MARTIN (27),
PLEADED GUILTY
to stealing a pint of brandy and other goods, of
Ann Gordon, his mistress, having been convicted of felony in September, 1876, at Clerkenwell—
Fifteen Months' Imprisonment. And

739.
WILLIAM GAYAN (38)
[Pleaded guilty: see original trial image]
, to stealing, as a servant, metal goods, the property of
the Queen—
Nine Months' Imprisonment.

740.
HENRY SHADD (22), and
WILLIAM THOMAS SHADD (17)
, Robbery on
William Smith, and stealing from his person, one watch and chain and three coins, his property.

WILLIAM SMITH . I am a plate layer, of 28, High Street, North Woolwich—on 28th July I was at the North Woolwich public-house, and the prisoner, Henry Shadd, put his hand on my shoulder and asked me if I was going home—he then snatched my watch from my waist-coat pocket, struck my mouth and made it bleed, and passed my watch to one of his mates—I got hold of him round the arms, held him till a policeman came, and gave him in custody—I did not see the other prisoner then, but after Henry had been remanded by the Magistrate, William came to me and said that he knew where the watch was, and he would give it to me if I would not prosecute his brother—I said that I would not, and he took the watch out of a white pocket handkerchief and gave it to me—I was afterwards told that I should get into trouble if I did not prosecute, so I told the sergeant, who took him in custody—this is my watch.

Cross-examined by Henry Shadd. I was not lying asleep on a chair at the Three Crowns—you tried to get away from me, and your mates tried to get you away—you stayed on the stairs with me, and said "You had better search those who are behind and send for a policeman"—the landlord turned me out and said that I had no watch on me—when we got outside you were free, you did not attempt to run away because a policeman was there.

ALFRED HOLDER (Policeman K 236). I was called and found Henry Shadd standing beside Smith outside the public-house—Smitn gave him in charge for stealing a watch and chain and a sovereign—he denied it and said that he was willing to go to the station—Smith appeared perfectly sober.
Cross-examined by Henry Shadd. You may have walked up to me, you and Smith both walked up together, and I cannot say which spoke first—you said "He has torn my coat;" your coat was torn.

LAWRENCE JOHN MANDERS (Policeman K 46). On 1st August, Smith pointed out William Shadd to me and I took him, and said that he very likely would be charged with receiving a watch and chain, knowing them to be stolen—he said "I know different to that, last evening a man came up to me in Albert Road, who I do not know, and gave me the watch and chain and asked me to have them passed back to the prosecutor, and said that he wanted a little recompense, but I did not give him anything"—I took him to the station and charged him with receiving—I found the broken bow of another watch on him—I was present on the night of the robbery, Smith appeared sober, the prisoner Henry accused him of being drunk—I said he is not drunk; he smelt a little of drink; he appeared to know very well what he was about.

p.hi: William, Shadd 'produced a written defence, stating that on the night after the robbery a man gave him the watch, stating that he picked it up under one of the tables at the Three Crowns, and asked him to restore it; to release his brother; who was his only support, and that he picked up the watch bow some months ago.

div1.p:
HENRY SHADD—
GUILTY —
Fine Months' Imprisonment.

W. T. SHADD—
NOT GUILTY .

741.
GEORGE CALLOW (21)
, Feloniously cutting and wounding
Edward Gay, with intent to do him grievous bodily harm.

EDWARD GAY . I live at 13, Perrin Street, Bromley—on the evening of August 7th, I had been drinking with the prisoner and his wife, and after
wards went to Western Street, where a row took place between my wife and the prisoner's wife—I and my wife went to fetch a baby, which had been left at Western Street—there was a young woman named Mrs. Clack, with a baby in her arms, and the prisoner shook hands with her—the prisoner's wife said "You had better take him home and sleep with him" and struck Mrs. Clack—my wife told her not to do that while she had her baby in her arms—the prisoner's wife was about to hit my wife, and I went to help her—my wife ran into the passage followed by the prisoner's wife—he stood in the doorway and said "If you come further into the passage I will bury this knife in your neck"—I went to my wife to get her away, and had not gone more than 2 feet when it was buried in my neck, and I fell out into the street insensible—there was a wound about 4 inches in length, I was in the hospital from Tuesday night till next Tuesday week.

Cross-examined. My wife is the prisoner's sister—I had been to three public-houses, but was not the worse for liquor, I do not know if he was—he struck me first—I said before the Magistrate I only struck him once, and saw a knife in his hand while he stood in the doorway, and it was dark in the passage and I did not see a knife, there were some people outside, I was struck just inside the passage; it was not dark—I saw the prisoner raise his arm to strike me; Julia Callow was not cut as well—I will nut swear to that—I have only been in prison once; I got two years' hard labour for doing nothing—I said before the Magistrate "I believe the prisoner struck me."

KERWIN (Policeman K 620). On 7th August I was called to Western Street, and saw the prosecutor lying on the pavement, with a wound nearly 4 inches in length—there was nearly 2 quarts of bloods, I never saw a man bleed much more—I took the prisoner—he said "It was not me
it was my sister, I do not see why I should suffer for her, and I will give her in charge for stabbing my wife also"—I did not see any knife.

Cross-examined. The prisoner did not ask me to go to the house and see his wife—I never saw her until 1 or 2 o'clock in the morning at the station, when she had been to hospital and had her wounds dressed, the prisoner's wife was cut—I saw only the bandages—I think the prisoner has been in a reformatory, but am not certain—I do not know that he has certificates of character from where he has been working—the passage is about 12 feet long, and 3 1/2 feet wide—I think the prisoner had been drinking.

SAMUEL SAUNDERS . I live at Tredegar Road, Bow—on 7th August, I saw the prisoner and prosecutor at the door having very high words, and the prisoner dared the prosecutor to enter the house—he said "If you come in here I will cut you"—I saw the prisoner's hand up and when he went in the prosecutor followed, but he had not been in two minutes before he came out and rolled and fell against a lamp-post—the women were inside fighting and hallooing "Murder"—I saw the prosecutor's wound and much blood.
Cross-examined. The passage was not altogether dark, a lamp throws a light about a yard across it—one of the women was cut—I am sure the word "cut" was used by the prisoner.
The Prisoner's Statement before the Magistrate: "I was not in my right mind, and don't know what I did."

742.
ROBERT COOPER CHAPPELL (52), and
MILES JOHN DOBSON (37)
, Unlawfully obtaining 1l. 1s., and other sums from
Samuel Ballard, by false pretences.
MESSRS. LILLIE and H. AVORY conducted the Prosecution; MR. W. SLEIGH appeared for Chapptll, and MR. SIMMS for Dobson.

SAMUEL BALLARD . I am a sandman and work for Mr. Lee, at the loam pits, Deptford—about February last, I was driving a cart, which was run into by another vehicle driven by Mr. Harriett's carman—I was taken to the hospital by a City officer, and four or five days after I came out I met the two prisoners in High Street, Deptford—my wife was on the other side of the way—I told them I had met with an accident, and must have somebody to write a letter for me—they said "Well, you may as well give the case into our hands"—they both said that; I knew them before and always thought Mr. Chappell was a solicitor—they said they would call on me in a day or two, and Mr. Chappell gave me this card "William Hicks, solicitor," with "Mr. Chappell" in the left hand corner—Chappell crossed out the address "3, Strickland Street, Deptfcrd," with a pencil and wrote "20, Prior Street, Greenwich"—about five days afterwards Dobsou drove up in a cab to my house—he came in and said "I shall charge you 5s., and. I will give you a. copy of the letter," and my wife gave him 5s., but we did not get the copy until we had paid a guinea for the writ—the letter looked like this. (Read: "14, Edward Street, February, 1877. Sir,—Not having received an answer to my letter of the 3rd instant, I called on you to-day, and unfortunately found you out. I must request your immediate answer relating to the matter, or if you will make an appointment here in the evening for Wed
nesday next. I am instructed to take immediate proceedings for damage and loss from your driver William Emerson to my client. (Signed)—M. J. Dobson.") About three weeks after that I met both the prisoners outside

the North Kent Railway Station, that is near the Amersham Arms—my wife was with me—they said "We shall want more money for further pro
ceedings, if not your bed will be taken from under you as we have done before"—they shewed us the copy of fhe letter that they had written and said "Neither of you can read, it is no use giving it to you"—my wife said "If it is no good to you it is no good to us; you had better give it to us," and she paid them a guinea and got this receipt for the money at the Amersham Arms: "February loth, 1877. Received of Samuel Ballard one guinea, on account of costs. Miles John Do! son"—eight or nine days after that they both came in a cab—my wife said again "I do not believe you are solicitors" he had said so at the Amersham Arras, and they both said Well, we should not take the money and represent ourselves so if we were not solicitors"—they wanted 23s. more to show an appearance in a higher court—my wife said "Then you will not have it"—they said "Then you will get yourselves into trouble and us too, and you will not have a bed to sleep on"—Dobson had got the witness's papers in the action in the City, who look me to the hospital, and (he second time he said "Now, pay me some more money and I will give you up the papers and get somebody else to take further proceedings"—I did not give him any more money—I shewed him some and he thought he was going to have five guineas, and pulled out a receipt, but 1 put the money in my pocket and said "Thank you, I will take it somewhere else"—they wanted five guiueas to take the case up to the Queen's Court at Westminster—they both said that—they did not go away—I walked out of the house and left them there—my wife was at home—I saw no more of them—I instructed somebody else and the result was a summons in this case—I authorised my wife to pay the money because I thought they were solicitors as they represented themselves.

Cross-examined by MR. SLEIGH. I have known Chappell about twelve years and always thought he was a solicitor—I have not seen him at police-courts—I was cross-examined at the police-court as to the offence for which I was tried—it was thirty years ago since I came out of Brixton for seven days—we were a lot of boys together in a field roasting laters, and twenty years ago 1 got three months for stealing a sack of beans—I have also had six months for gambling in 1866—I have been home thirteen years and nobody can say anything against me—I call it gambling, it was for stealing money from the person—there was not six months for gambling us well—the first statement I made to the Magistrate was that Chappell gave me the card and my wife paid the money—I had to admit in cross-examination that I had the card five days before any money was paid—I cannot read much, nor can my wife—we did not read the card—nobody read it to us till I took it to the solicitor—I saw the prisoner outside the Centurion at Deptford, and told them that I had had a horse killed—I did not say "I have got a bit of a law job on"—I said "I have got a bit of a hard job on"—I said I should have to get somebody to attend to it for me—I did not go for the purpose of getting Chappell to attend to it—they stopped me and said "Halloo, Bailard, how are you getting on?" and I told them, and they said "If you are going to have anybody you might as well put it in our way, we are both solicitors"—when I said I had a bit of a law job on 1 intended to ask Chappell to do it for me, thinking he was a solicitor—I should not have told them anything about it or asked them to attend to it if 1 had not thought they were soli
citors—Chappell said that he could not stop to talk the matter over then

and I went away—it was five days before I saw them and paid any money—the next time I saw them was on 15th February, at the Amersham Arms, when I paid the money, but Dobson got the 5s. at ray house when Chappell was not there—I did not go to the Amersham Arms for the purpose of seeing them, they met me in my cart and told me to meet them—I sent my wife to see if they were there and they were both there—I did not ask Chappell which was the cheapest way to take a summons out in the Mayor's Court, or the County Court, nor did he tell me that if Mr. Harriett was in the jurisdiction of the Mayor's Court it would be cheaper to go there—the Mayor's Court was mentioned; it was to be taken there for 23s., that was to show an. appearance—I had had that card five days before that—I went into the Amersham Arms and came out again—they both represented themselves to me as solicitors outside the Amersham Arms—I did' not say before the Magistrate that nothing of the sort was said at the Amersham Arms; I said that it was not said inside.

Cross-examined by MR. SIMMS. I think Dobson was a partner with Mr. Hobbs, a cab proprietor—I have not spoken to him on Hobbs' premises—I do not know but what he was Hobbs' solicitor—I thought he was a partner, being always there—I have made a mistake, Clayton and Hobbs were part
ners and I thought he was their solicitor, I heard he was; that was ten or eleven years ago—I thought he was Clayton, because I did not know Clayton then—I did not think he was a cab proprietor wheu I saw him, because I had heard different before then—I never knew him with a brewer—I saw him at Epsom Races a few years ago standing by a brewer'svan—he did. not serve me with some beer—I did not know he was in the service of a brewer at that time—I was examined before my wife at the police-court—I mentioned both interviews—I did not send a boy for Dobson to New Cross.

Re-examined. It is twelve years since I was last convicted—since that time I have been constantly in employment—I am still in Mr. Lee's employ
ment and have been about fifteen years—if I had known that the prisoners were not solicitors I should not have employed them.

EMMA BALLARD . I am the wife of the last witness—he met with an acci
dent and was taken to the hospital—I was with him at the beginning of February when he met the prisoners near the Centurion—I was on the opposite side of the way—I saw him speak to them and saw Chappell hand, him a card—about a week after that Dobson drove up to our house in a cab and said that he had written a letter to Mr. Harriett about the accident and he read a copy of the letter to my husband and asked 5s. for writing it—I heard that and I said "Are you a solicitor?"—he said "Yes, me and Mr. Chapell are both solicitors; you don't suppose, Mrs. Ballard, we would come and take your husband's case in hand unless we were solicitors," and upon that I paid him 5s.—on 15th February, about 10 or 11 o'clock in the day, in consequence of something my husband told me, I went with him to the Amersham Arms, where we found the prisoners in a compartment—there was one tall gentleman there besides—they told my husband that they wanted a guinea to serve a writ upon Mr. Harriett—I said in their hearing "I don't think they are solicitors"—they both said "You don't suppose we should take your husband's money unless we were solicitors," and when 1 paid Dobson the money to get the writ, he read the copy of the letter again to my husband, who said "You may as well give me that letter"—he said "As you cannot read it the letter is of no use to you"—my husband said "It is no use to we and no use to you," and then he gave the copy to ray husband who asked

for a receipt for the guinea—they said they did not think he wanted a receipt for a guinea and they would have to go to the Queen's Court to get the writ—they gave him this receipt, I put it on the file and the copy of the letter too—I should not have paid the money if they had not represented themselves as solicitors—they both said "We cannot go just yet, we must wait here till 12 o'clock to see a lady on the same business, as her husband has met with an accident, and one journey will serve for two—we met the prisoners a couple of weeks afterwards coming out of a railway station and Dobson said "Mrs. Ballard, I want you to give me 235."—my husband said "What for?"—Chappell said "For putting in an appearance"—I said to my husband "I don't think I should let them have anymore"—he said "I don't think I shall let you have any more," and Chappell said "If you do not give Us the money you will get into a great deal of trouble, you will have everything taken from you, and not only that you will be sent to prison besides"—I saw them three or four times after that, and on each occasion they asked my husband for money.

Cross-examined by MR. W. SLEIGH. The first occasion when I saw the card given was February 3rd—I paid the 5s. about the 10th—the first time I saw them was at the Amersham Arms on the 15th—my husband and I both went in, I am sure of that—my husband did not remain outside—I saw all the business that was transacted that day at the Amersham Arms—I did not go inside the Amersham Arms to fetch my husband—we both walked into the compartment and found them there—what they said was "Law, Mrs. Ballard, you are not afraid to trust us with a guinea, are you?" and then I paid'him the guinea—I said at the police-court "A guinea for the writ"—they said that the writ would cost him a guinea; that is in my depositions.
Cross-examined by MR. SIMMS. The first time I went to the police-court I was not examined; my husband was examined and I was examined ten days afterwards.

GEORGE POWELL . I am an officer in the Mayor's Court, London—I pro
duce an affidavit sworn there on 15th February, 1877, at the same time as the issue of a precept; I did not see it sworn, it is signed "John Dobson;" it is an action between Samuel Ballard and R. Harriett to recover 21l.—the attorney's name is William Hicks, 30, Strickland Street, Deptford—that affidavit was made for the purpose of serving the plaint out of the jurisdic
tion; it is necessary for the person who makes that to be a solicitor—judg
ment of non pros was entered on 26th March in consequence of the plaintiff not proceeding with the action; upon that the defendant would be entitled to judgment for his costs, and the plaintiff, in order to get the action renewed, would have to get that judgment set aside.

Cross-examined by MR. W. SLEIGH. The person swearing that affidavit need not be a solicitor or agent—in a case over 20l. a summons would cost 7s.—there would be a fee of 1s. on this affidavit, 2s. for the oath, and 5s. for the action—the oficer who serves the summons is entitled to 3s. 6d., that would make half a guinea, which would be altogether the cost of this summons, but if issued in Lincoln's Inn Fields, the cost would be 1l. 17s. 2d. if paid within eight days without the cab fares if served within three miles—the whole sum paid in this case was 7s.—the rest is what the defendant would have had to pay if he had appeared.
Cross-examined by MR. SIMMS. There was no agency in this case—if the defendant gives notice of defence he has to notify to the plaintiff that he
has done so, and whatever costs were incurred in the matter, would be costs in the cause.

WILLIAM HICKS . I am a solicitor of Virginia Villas, Grove Street Road, South Hackney—up to March, 1874, I had an office at 30, Strickland Street, Deptford, which I have relinquished—Cbappeu was my clerk, but ceased to be so when I left that office—I never gave him authority to use my name on any occasion to Samuel Ballard, against Harriett—this card was a card used by me about 5 years ago—the body of this affidavit is in Chappell's writing, and the signature is his, as also the precipe—I do not know Dobson or his signature—I saw him first at Greenwich.

Cross-examined by MR. W. SLEIGH. I have known Chappell many years—during the time he was in my employ I always found him to be fully capable aud a man of business—he used to manage the criminal portion of my business at this Court, and at. the Middlesex Sessions and police-courts—he gave me every satisfaction—I did not interfere in what he did—he attended to the County Court and Mayor's Court work—I had one or two letters from Mr. Moss, and the name of Chappell might have been in the first—I have not got the letter with me, I dare say Mr. Moss has a copy—I have only seen Chappell once since he left me in March, or April, 1874—except since this case has been going on—I am not aware whether he has been at my office several times in the last three or four years, but he has written there—I was from home a great deal in the early part of February—if he bad introduced any business to me I should have taken it in hand, and this being a little matter at Greenwich, I should have allowed him to take it in hand, because he would see the people more often than I should. myself—I have spoken to him about introducing business to me—I asked him at Cannon Street Station about twelve months ago, if he had left Mr. Seards. (The Law List was here put in, shewing that the Defendants—names did not appear in it as solicitors.)
MRS. KALLARD (re-examined). I cannot read.
GUILTY .

CHAPPELL—
Three Months' Imprisonment.
DOBSON received a good character—
One Month's Imprisonment.

743.
ELIZABETH BROWNLOW (38),
PLEADED GUILTY
to unlawfully uttering counterfeit coin, after a previous conviction of a like offence in June, 1873—
Nine Months' Imprisonment.

744.
MORRIS HARRIS (38), and
JOSEPH ALLEN (55)
, Stealing 1,170 yards of silk, and 15 yards of rep, the property of
Joseph Spiers.

JOSEPH SPIERS . I am a trimming manufacturer, of 18, Union Street, Borough, and carry on business as Spiers and Sons—on 30th May, my clerk Fortune called my attention to my stock—missed 990 yards of white silk, value at 123l. 15s. at 2s. 6d.; also a piece of crimson sarsnet, value 20l. 1s. 3d. at 3s. 9d.; and 62 yards of white Italian silk at 1s. 10d., 5l. 13s. 8d.; 62 yards of white sarsnet at 3s. 10l., 10l. 17s.;15 yards of rep at 1s., 15s.; the total value is 161l. 1s. 10d.—I also missed 74 pieces of binding at 10s. 6d., 38l. 17s.; 20 yards of brown quilt at 6s., 6l.; and 10 yards of button covering at 6s.; total of 208l. 18s. 11d.—I saw that pro
perty

safe at 4 o'clock on the afternoon of 29th, except the rep, which I Lad not seen for a week or two—I gave information to the police—I saw my manager, Onsey, on 11th June—I went to the police-station and saw the eleven pieces of silk of 100 yards each—I do not know the prisoners—I never sell the silk in that condition; we sell it cut up for cap lining—one piece bad been in nay possession a fortnight, and some only two days—such silk is never sold at 10d. a yard—I also identified the rep—I have had it six months—it has changed colour; it has been made fifteen years.
Cross-examined by MR. STRAIGHT. These samples were left at my place.

Cross-examined by MR. RIBTON. This rep was used for bonnets—I have no marks upon it—a piece could not be produced the same colour, as it has faded—it was manufactured in Spitalfields—other houses might have been supplied with it at the time that was made—if I said I had had it fifteen years, that is a mistake; it has been made fifteen years—I corrected that mistake before the Magistrate—I said I had it to sell for a friend, a neigh
bour—I was not asked his name.
Re-examined. It could not be died that colour—I have not the slightest doubt that it is my property—I never knew silk like that sold on barrows in the street.

ALEXANDER ONSEY . I am manager to the prosecutor—on 11th June I was in the warehouse, and saw the property which was stolen on 29th or 30th May—the prisoner Harris' father came to me on June 11th and offered me some patterns of silk—I saw at once that they were the goods we had lost, and made arrangements to see him again the following morning—he gave me this card. (M. Harris, wholesale shirt manufacturer and ware-houseman, 8, Great Prescott Street, London.) I saw the bulk at his place of business the next morning at 11 o'clock, in Great Prescott Street—he showed me a piece at a time, till I saw the whole of them; there were eleven pieces—he brought them from under the counter, where he was writing—he said the price would be 1s. 2d. per yard all round, and it amounted to 68l. 5s.—the value of the white silk is 2s. 2d. to 2s. 6d. a yard; the white sarsnet, 3s. 3d. to 3s. 6d.; the coloured crimson, 3s. 3d. to 3s. 9d.; the Italian cloth, 1s. 10d.—I got a cab and said "Will you put them in the cab? we may as well take them to the warehouse, and Mr. Spiers can decide the purchase"—they were put into the cab, and we drove a certain distance—when we went down Great Prescott Street the prisoner Harris got into the cab—we stopped at a public-house where the police had arranged to meet me, and from there the police took Harris and the silk to the station—this is the memorandum of the quantities shown to me by Harris—he did not write it in my presence.

RICHARD KIMBER (Detective Officer). In consequence of a conversation with Mr. Spiers, on 12th June, I went to Great Prescott Street in a cab with Mr. Onsey—I waited outside; some parcels were brought out and placed in a cab—Onsey and Harris got into the cab—we went to Southwark Street and stopped at a public-house called the Metropolitan, at the corner of Southwark Bridge Road—Harris and Onsey got out; I went to Harris and said "I am a detective and Pether is another; what have you got in the brown-paper parcel in the cab?"—he said "Parcels of silk"—I said "We have had several robberies in the neighbourhood, will you account for the possession of that silk?"—he said "I bought it of a man named Johnson"—I said "Where does Johnson live?"—he said "I bought six or seven days ago, either Wednesday or Thursday, and Johnson resides at Shadwell

and keeps an outfitter's shop and boarding-house for sailors"—I asked him for the receipt or invoice—he said "I have one at home on my file"—I said "Was it a cash transaction?"—he said "I paid part in cash and part by cheque; Johnson has owed me money for some time; I paid him 10d. a yard for the silk, the amount I cannot say till I see the receipt which is on my file at home"—I then went to the Thames police-court and obtained a search warrant, and Harris was taken to the station while I made investigations—I and Pether went to Johnson's house and had a conversation with him—we found this receipt on this file in his shop "Received of Mr. Johnson 27l. for silk"—I then went with Johnson to 10l., St. John Street Road, Clerkenwell, a private ten-roomed house in the main street; he pointed out the prisoner Allen in a room in that house facing the street, and said "This is the man I bought the silk of"—I said to Allen "You hear what this man says; I am a detective, and Pether who is with me is another. That silk is stolen from a warehouse in Southwark Street; I want you to account for the possession of it"—he said "I bought it of a man for samples"—I said "When and where?—he said "I bought it of a man in a public-house in the City Road"—I said 'What is the man's name, and the sign of the house?"—he said he did not know, I then asked him for a description of the man—he said "I cannot give you one"—I held the receipt up and said "Here is a receipt for 29l. that Johnson paid you"—he said "Well, I did not write that receipt, that is not my writing"—Johnson said "You were present when it was written"—Allen said "Yes, but it is 29l., not 27l."—I then said "Did you receive that 29l."—he said "Yes, I received it and paid it to the man who brought the silk, and he gave me a half sovereign for my trouble"—I asked him if he had got any receipt or invoice; he said "No"—I said "I will search your house"—in the kitchen drawer I found this piece of black ribbon—I asked him how he accounted for it"—he said "I bought it some five or six days ago"—I said "When and where?—he said "I bought it in the street of an old clothes woman, off a barrow"—I said "What street? how much did you give for it"—he said "5s"—I took Allen and Johnson to the station, and they were charged with stealing the goods—I went to Harris, the father's house, in the evening, and he gave me this receipt "Bought of F. Johnson, 1,160 yards of silk at 10d. a yard, 48l. 6s. 8d., received by cheque aud counter account"—Johnson, Allen, and Harris were all committed for trial, and were to be tried last Session—Johnson did not surrender to hie bail, and a Bench warrant was issued—I have been to his house every
thing has been removed.
Cross-examined by MR. STRAIGHT. The name of Harris is over the door in Prescott Street—Lewis Harris, the father gave me the receipt from among some papers.

Cross-examined by MR. RIBTON. No silk was produced at Allen's house—in conversation Allen was told Harris was detained at the station, and that the silk was identified as stolen—no quantity was mentioned, nor the quality nor colour—he said "I bought it some weeks ago of an old woman in the street"—I said "What street"—he said "She stands in the street with a barrow."

EDWARD FOUTUNE . I am clerk to the prosecutor, I was in the warehouse on 29th May, I locked up that night; I went downstairs at 6.45 the next morning, and found the doors between the hall and the warehouse open; the chain was hanging loose and the bolts drawn—the drawers were all pulled open and left so, and parcels strewn about the floor—I afterwards
went with a detective to the elder Harris' house and found these pieces of silk.

SUSAN ORAM . I am the wife of Frederick Taylor Oram, a clerk and commisson agent, of 101, St. John Street Road, Clerkenwell—Allen and his wife in May occupied the breakfast parlour facing the street—I heard of his being taken—shortly before that I saw some silk in his room—I saw it taken away in a horse cloth by two men, one was named Johnson; I saw the rep lying in the same breakfast parlour on a couch—Allen went with the men.

Cross-examined by MR. STRAIGHT. All this was done openly—I saw the silk, I believe, on 5th June—I cannot say when it came—it might have been in the house a week—it was a pure white silk—I did not closely examine it—it was not similar to this produced, but softer—I could not tell you how much there was; I did not count the pieces, because it was usual for Allen to buy things to sell—I was not astonished to see it there.

LEWIS HARRIS . I live with my son Morris Harris, at 8, Great Prescott Street, where he carries on business as a shirt manufacturer and warehouseman—my age is seventy-five; my son keeps me and I help him in the business—I know Johnson—he is a sailors' outfitter in Shadwell, and has dealt with my son—in May he owed my son 20l. odd, I called for it scores of times, twice or three times a day—on 4th June, Johnson brought me some samples of silk, and I told my son I could not get Johnson to pay my money, and that he would sell it in part payment of his debt—it was about 1,000 yards—I Johnson afterwards called on my son and asked if the silks would suit him as he would take it off his debt and added, "And the balance you can pay me in goods or cheque or both"—he asked 1s. a yard for it, and then 10d. as my son had had so much trouble—my son said he would see it and give him an answer—he saw it next morning and said he would take it at 10d. in the afternoon—Johnson came again in the afternoon, the account was gone into and my son signed this cheque for 22l., and this receipt for 48l. was given him by Johnson, my son giving Johnson 6l. in goods, and the cheque for 22l. to make up the balance, the debt being 20l.—about two days after I went to Messrs. Spiers with a sample of the silk—my son did not know of my going; he does not attend to this part of the business—I went back to Prescott Street, and told my son of an appointment which had been made for between 10 and 11 o'clock on the morrow when Mr. Spiers foreman was coming down, and the foreman did come down, and I was there when the silk was shown—I had left the price 1s. 2d. a yard at Mr. Spiers' warehouse, which is a fair price for such a house, as they often want discount; I gave Johnson's receipt to the officer—it was among the invoices which my son had prepared to post at the end of the month.

Cross-examined by MR. M. WILLIAMS. 1s. 2d. is a fair price as a job lot—I have dealt in silk for sixty years—my son might have bought small pieces of silk, but to the best of my knowledge I do not think he has had any transactions of that kind—he generally attends to the business—I go out, or serve customers when he is out—my son buys and sells, I cannot bring to my mind my son's buying silk of Johnson before—my son keeps the book produced—Johnson used to supply the sailors with goods and the ships with sailors—he had two shops in Ratcliffe Highway—he kept a sailor's lodging-house—we do not make shirts out of silk like this—the value of this silk'is about 2s. 6d. or 2s. 8d.—if Mr. Spiers has sworn it is worth 3s. 9d., that is

an extravagant price—to buy it as a job lot, it is worth about 2s., or 3d. less—as a bankrupt's stock, I dare say I could get it for 1s. 6d.—I should call it a job lot, because it is out of order—I was present when it was delivered by Johnson and another man in a cart—the bargain took place about the 5th.

PAMILA SAMUELS . I am a draper in White Alie Street—I buy job lots of silk sometimes—I have been in business twelve years—Mr. Harris shewed me some samples of silk in the early part of June—I do not remember the date—I looked at them—he said he had been asking 1s. a yard for them—I said they were worth that—I would not give 2s. 2d. a yard for them—Mr. Harris made no concealment about it—I have been in my present, residence ten years—I have known Harris since he was a boy—he is a respectable tradesman—I have brought job lots of silk of Pawsons, of Lewis, and Cooks, and form my opinion from my general experience.

Cross-examined by MR. M. WILLIAMS. Mine is a large business—this silk is not worth more than 2s. a yard, but I am used to buying in job lots and damaged goods, so I should not like to say—I should not call this perfect, because of the way it is rolled up.

LAWRENCE SAMUEL . I live at 38, Mansell Street, and am a job draper—my parents have been in business fifty years, and I have been in business six years—I was at Mr. Harris' premises on 5th June—he asked me what I thought some samples of silk were worth—I replied that it was difficult to give a precise judgment about that class of goods, because the qualities are so various, and I did not want to buy them, but I believed they were worth about lid a yard—I have been in the habit of attending large sales, and I. have seen goods of a similar quality fetch 10d., 11d., 1s., and 1s. 1d. per yard—I have known Harris all my life—I was in a situation with him many years—he has borne a high character amongst his neighbours for honesty and integrity.

Cross-examined by MR. M. WILLIAMS. The silk produced is worth about 2s. a yard—you may easily be deceived in silk—this other is perhaps worth about 1s. 6d. a yard, but I doubt if you were to offer it for sale that you would get more than 11d. a yard for it—there are three qualities of silk here, but to an experience eye they might all be taken as one—any silk that has been unfolded I should call irregular, and it would not fetch so much.
JOHN PEARTREE . I am a hat and cap manufacturer—the silk produced is used for lining bats; there are three qualities here, one is worth about 2s. a yard, and the others 1s. 4d. or 1s. 6d.
Cross-examined. The red silk would be worth about 2s. 8d. a yard in its present state being out of order.

JOSEPH SPIERS (re-examined). I have carried on business in the silk trade 30 years—these silks are not ordinary widths such as draper's goods, which are 18 to 21 inches; these are 36 inches wide—the last witnesses have valued them as drapers widths.

HARRIS received a good character—
NOT GUILTY .

ALLEN—
GUILTY *—
Five Years' Penal Servitude.

745.
MARY AYMEK (29)
, Stealing a table, two looking glasses, ten yards of muslin and other goods, the property of
William Butler.
FRANCIS WILLIAM BUTLER . I am a furniture dealer of 8, Stamford Street,

Blackfriars—I produce an agreement for the hire of some household furniture—the prisoner signed it; it contains a list of the articles. (This agreement was dated 27th February, 1877, and was for the hire of some furniture by On prisoner from the prosecutor, at the rate of 15s. a week, payable quarterly the prisoner to have the option of purchasing within 12 months, the prosecutor in default of payment to take possession of the goods). I have since seen the goods at different pawnbrokers, and identified them—there are seven or eight articles such as looking glasses, and lamps, and other things—I know nothing about a bill of sale on them.

Cross examined. I first knew the prisoner in December, 1876—I did not know her during her husband's life; I believe she has a good deal of furniture in her rooms—she lived in Trigon Road, Clapham—she bought a looking glass of me in December, 1876, and paid me 2l. 10s. for it; she did not bur a dining table, she had that on hire—previous to the agreement she paid me between 12l. and 13l. for goods—in respect to the agreement she paid me 50s. on 28th February, 20s. on 5th March, 40s. on 12th March, 20s. on 17th April, 10s. on 13th April; I gave her a receipt—the value of the goods was about 75l.—she did not pay the weekly payments regularly; the payments were to go towards the purchase—I was sent for to the police court; I have no wish to prosecute—I did not give her in custody—I saw the prisoner's sister, and an arrangement was entered into with the Magistrate's sanction with the pawnbrokers to redeem the goods—the prisoner's sister handed me some pawn tickets to get the goods—I find that the prisoner has got into the hands of loan offices—I know she took in dress making, she seemed to be always at work—she had assistants; she has complained of being robbed of material, which she was at great trouble and expense to replace.
By THE COURT. The value of the things pawned was about 20l., 10l. had been advanced upon them.

ALEXANDER HENRY DAVIS . I live at 20, Penton Place, Kennington, and am managing clerk to Mr. Carpenter, of 106, Stand; he lends money—I produce two bills of sale, one for 13l. 10s., and the other for 20l., executed by the prisoner—she received 10l. on the 13l. 10s. bill, and 15l. on the 20l., bill, to be repaid by monthly instalments.

Cross-examined. She was to pay 3l. 5s. a month on the two bills—the schedule is in the second bill—we do not as a rule take a second inventory when there are two bills of sale, the schedule answers to both—the schedule is placed in the second bill of sale by mistake.
Re-examined. The 25l. advanced covered the furniture in the house—she stated the furniture was her own, otherwise I should not have advanced the money—she has paid 4l. 10s.

CHARLES SELLS . I am a pawnbroker of 146, Claphara Road—I produce duplicates for a piece of muslin, a table cover, two curtains, a soup bowl two sauce tureens, a lamp, a second lamp, a time piece, a swing glass, a pillow, a chimney glass, and an oval table, upon which I advanced 10l. at different dates between March and May—those goods have been identified by the prosecutors.

CHARLES SKINNER . I am assistant to Mr. Matthews, of Prince's Row, Kennington Cross, pawnbroker—the prisoner pledged at our shop four pictures on 23rd May, for 16s., and a curtain and other articles on 3rd May, for 5s., in the name of Ann Davis—Mr. Butler has identified them. Mary Ann Deadman. I am the wife of John Deadman, and female

searcher at Rochester Row police-station—I searched the prisoner when she was brought to the station, and found some papers and duplicates rolled up—she asked me to keep them for her—I gave them up to the sergeant.
WILLIAM BLATCHFORD (Policeman B 454). I took the prisoner—a number of pawn tickets were given to me relating to furniture—the tickets have been seen by the pawnbrokers and by the prosecutor.

MR. STRAIGHT submitted that tin prisoner was part owner of the goods, and here before there was no case to go to the Jury; also that she had never really converted the goods, as the pawn tickets could be handed to the prosecutor at any moment, the prisoner had only obtained money on the goods, and the time within which they were to be returned had not expired. See" Reg. v. Hutchinson." At the suggestion of THE COURT the Jury returned a verdict of

746.
WALTER CHARLES STAFFORD (25)
, Embezzling the sums of 43l. 2s. 6d., 1821. 10s., and 42l. 10s., of
George Pain, his master.

hi.rs: The Jury, after three hours' consultation, being unable to agree, were discharged without giving a verdict.

div1.p:
747.
ROBERT JAMES HALL (42)
, Burglariously breaking and entering the dwelling-house of
George Williams, and stealing therein 3s., his money.

Elizabeth Williams. I am the wife of
George Williams, who keeps the Horns Tavern, Rotherhithe—on 16th August, about 4 a.m., the police knocked at our door, I went down and found the front parlour window, about 4 or 5 inches open, which I closed the night before about 12 o'clock, 3s. had been taken from a little shelf behind the bar, not in the same room where the window was open—the prisoner is a waterman plying at the Horns Stairs—he is a customer of mine, and had been at the house that night till closing time.
Cross-examined by MR. FULTON. He has been a customer about two or three years—he is a licensed waterman.

JAMES MAGDURE (Policeman R. 392). On the night of 15th August, I was on my beat at the Horns Stairs, and saw the prisoner, at several intervals from 11 till 4 o'clock in the morning—at 4 o'clock I did not find him at the stairs—I went to examine the Horns tavern and found the window about 3 or 4 inches up with the light of my bull's eye I saw the prisoner stand
ing on the parlour floor against a table with his arms folded towards the wall—I recognised him as the man I had seen on the stairs—a lamplighter came past and 1 borrowed his stick and told him to stand at the window while I rapped at the door—when Mr. Williams came down I went into the house—I saw the prisoner come round to the back door while I was at the front door—he went over the fence down on to the water, I took a boat directly and went over the water to Limebouse, but could not see anything of the prisoner there, the other boat was about halfway across before I started—I did not see what became of the prisoner; I rowed back again—before I started in pursuit I saw the waterman Butcher there, I had not seen be risoner before 11 o'clock that night, I did not know him or his name.
Cross-examined. When I first saw the prisoner he was lying on the stairs,

I could not tell Whether asleep or drunk—there was a lamp above him; I looked down on the top of him, but took no further notice of him—I thought he was waiting for a waterman; I did not know he was a waterman—I looked at the prisoner at 11.30, 12.30, 1.30, 2.30, and 3.30—I did not ask him what he was doing there—I have not been in the force very long—I could not see the back door from the front door.
Re-examined. I was outside the Horns, when I saw the man go out at the back door.

THOMAS BUTCHER . I am a watchman employed at Canada Wharf, Rother
hithe, I was passing the Horns stairs, about 3.50 this morning, and saw the prisoner there—I tried to wake him, but could not—about 4.5 I saw him standing in the passage of the Horns on the stairs alongside our premises—I did not speak to him—I afterwards saw him in a boat rowing downward, and called out to him "Is that you Bob" and he said "Yes Tom, do you want a hoat?"—I said "No," at the same time a man called out for a boat, and he rowed him over in Mr. Fryer's boat.
Cross-examined. I have known the prisoner two or three years—he is a licensed waterman and plies there, taking both night and day jobs—it is usual for night watermen to sleep on the station.

JAMES MIDDLETON (Detective Officer R). I took the prisoner at the Horns public-house on 16th, about 12.30 and told him the charge—he said "I was here last night, but left about 4 o'clock this morning, and rowed a fare to the Surrey Canal, and I know nothing of him"—I found 2d. on him.
Cross-examined by MR. BRINDLEY. I arrested him in the very public-house where this is said to have taken place.
NOT GUILTY .

748.
MARTIN PFEIFFER (40)
, Stealing 50 Napoleons and other coins, the property of
Wiihelm Bergman.

WILHELM BERGMAN (through, an interpreter). I am a merchant and live in Poland, I bad been in England five months in May, or June, 1877—I do not know whether that was the date of my going or of my coming back—I do not know a word of English; I corresponded with the prisoner before I left here—I arrived in London again on Wednesday, 8th August, and put up at the hotel Causier, 23, Broad Street, Bloomsbury, and telegraphed to the prisoner announcing my arrival in London—he came to my hotel the same night about 6 o'clock, and I had a conversation with him in Polish—he told me he should be able to purchase some Chamois skins—he did not say who from, only that he would call next day about them—he said that to-morrow about noon we should go to the merchant, but did not give me the merchant's address—about 11 o'clock next morning his wife called and I went with her to 43, Clifton Crescent, Peckham, where they live—we went into the dining-room where I saw the prisoner in bed, he said that he had caught cold and had sent for the merchant who would be there in two hours—I remained there, and at the end of that time Mrs. Pfeiffer came upstairs and said that the merchant had arrived—the prisoner put his clothes on and went down with me to the merchant, whom I had never seen before—I have since pointed him out at the Cafe Monico, in Piccadilly, to Mr. Woolf; his name is David Von Hand—the would be merchant produced a little bag in which there was one Chamois skin as a sample, and they conversed in English which I did not understand—I examined one skin and made a bargain for

170 dozen of them, which amounted to 450l. English—Pfeiffer asked me twice to give the money to the merchant—I said that as I had the pleasure of seeing the merchant for the first time in my life and did not know him, I would rather not part with my money until I got the skins—they conversed together and Pfeiffer sent out for some brandy, and we had a glass together—it was arranged for Pfeiffer and the merchant to come to my hotel, and we were all to go to the warehouse and inspect the skins—no address was given where the skins were—Pfeiffer told me that I could trust any amount of money with the merchant, that he had had transactions with him to a very large amount—after several attempts made by Pfeiffer to induce me to part with my money to the merchant, he told me to give it to him, and I gave him a deposit, for which this receipt produced was written; the body of it is in my writing and the signature is Pfeiffer's—the figures on the receipt stamp are mine—I gave him 2,200 Prussian bank-notes, marks, and 1,000 francs in French gold. (The receipt as translated was for 2,200 Prussian bank-notes, and 1,000 francs; as a deposit for the purchase of 130 dozen Chamois skins; to be returned if the bargain was not concluded, and signed Martin Pfeiffer, 10th August, 1877.) The date is a mistake, it took place on Thursday, the 9th—the next day Pfeiffer came to my hotel without the merchant—he said that the merchant had not come, no doubt something had happened to him and I must be quite easy, very likely I should see him to-morrow—next day Pfeiffer came again without the merchant and said that most likely very important business had kept him from coming on so slight an affair—I smelt that the business was not right and said "This is not bond-fide business, it looks like a swindle"—on the following Sunday I went to Pfeiffer at Peckham, and told him to go to the—merchant—I said "I do not want any skins, give me my money back"—he said "I have not got the money, I gave it to the merchant"—being Sunday he said "We cannot go and see him, the merchant does not live in. London, he is only a travelling merchant"—we went on that very Sunday to look after him in a public-house or coffee-house—he told me that generally the merchant was there about 6 o'clock in the evening and very likely we might meet him there, but the place was shut up—Pfeiffer then told me he should try and find him to-morrow, and for certain he would come to me on the Monday, and said that he was not able to find him—I asked for the merchant's home and residence; he told me he did not know it himself, that he only met him in that coffee-house—he had said on Monday that the merchant was a Frenchman—I saw Pfeiffer every day after that—I returned to Nottingham on Sunday, 19th August, and returned on the following Tuesday with Mr. Woolf—with the exception of those days I saw Pfeiffer every day until I gave him in custody—I kept secret that I wanted to arrest differ; I did not see him after the 16th—I went to Dover on Thursday, the 16th, that was the Thursday before I went to Nottingham—the prisoner went with me to the station, and was with me up to the starting of the train—I paid for my ticket; I asked the prisoner for my money, and he said I should have it when I got into the carriage—when the train was going to start I asked him for the 5l.—I told him I was going to Poland, but my intention was to keep secret in London that I might arrest him—I did not. get the 5l.—I wished him good-bye, the train started, and he stopped at the station—he was taken custody on Wednesday night, August 22nd, after which Mrs. Pfeiffer gave me a card of Mr. Kipps, of Bermondsey—I went there on Saturday, 25th August with Mr. Woolf, who spoke to Mr. Kipps in.
English—I had already taken out a warrant—I gave evidence twice, once before I saw Mr. Kipps, and once afterwards.

Cross-examined. I had a shop of all sorts in Poland—I have never had a business transaction with the prisoner; he went with me about business but I did not do business with him before—I went with Mrs. Pfeiffer to Gatti's restaurant, and from there to the Canterbury Music Hall after dinner—she left me there and went home alone—the word "Chamois" is not in this receipt, it is "Skins"—it was written at Charing Cross Station, not at Peckham—Ffeiffer said he was rather unwell and wanted to take fresh air, and asked me to go for a stroll, and he gave me this receipt after a couple of hours' walking about; but I was at his house from 12 o'clock till 4.30—the would-be merchant stayed with us about an hour and a half, and when he left I was left alone with Pfeiffer for a couple of hours longer—I went out with Pfeiffer about 5 o'clock—he went home from Charing Cross about 7 o'clock and I met Mrs. Pfeiffer about 7.30—I said before the Magistrate that he gave me the receipt marked A at the time—that is true; he gave it me the same day, at Charing Cross—I pressed him to give it to me, and he said "Well, let us go to the station and I will give it you"—I did not know that Gatti's is close by—this is very likely the first time I have mentioned its being written at Charing Cross—they did not ask me the question before the Magistrate—it was not written on the 16th—after the conversation between Mr. Woolf and Mr. Kipps, Mr. Woolf told me that Kipps was willing to give 200l. for Mr. Pfeiffer—we remained there half an hour.

Re-examined. Pfeiffer gave me the card with Kipps' address, and said he would see me—Mr. Woolf spoke to Kipps in English, and he told me that Mr. Kipps was willing to give me 150l. back of the money, and 50l. for expenses incurred, to get Pfeiffer out of prison—Woolf told me I must go to a solicitor—I did not propose any compromise through Woolf—he told me the matter was already in the Justices' hands, and the best thing would be for him to go to the solicitor of this man.

DAVID VON HAND . I keep an hotel at 23, Broad Street, Golden Square, about three minutes' walk from the Hotel de Versailles—four or five days after Bergman arrived, and after 13th August, Stanislas, an interpreter, was pointed out to me at the Cafe Monaco, and I saw him every day at Charing Cross Station—he takes people from there to hotels, and I think he has something to do with the Hotel de Versailles—he is a Pole—I have not seen him since the prosecutor has been at the police-court, but the evening afterwards I saw him with a number of gentlemen at the Argyle—I have since been at the place where I used to see him, and have not seen him.
Cross-examined. I have known Stanislas more than two years at Charing Cross Station.

WILLIAM WOOLF . I am a Pole, and live in Nottingham—I am not in business now—on Sunday, 19th August, Bergman came down to me and on Tuesday, 21st, I came to London with him—we went to the Cafe Monarco the same evening with Mr. Von Hand—Bergman pointed out a man to Mr. Von Hand and gave me this card of Mr. Kipps (produced)—I went to Mr. Kipps on the Saturday with Bergman, and told him all the circumstances——he said that Mrs. Pfeiffer had been, to him and wished him to come to some arrangement—he asked me what arrangement we could come to—I said "I do not know that we can come to any arrangement ourselves, I think the solicitors will have to come to an arrangement"—he said "No, we can manage

that ourselves, she suggested to me to give you a draft at a month"—he did not say for how much—I asked him what a draft was—he said "An accept
ance like these," showing me some—he asked me what we should be satisfied with—I said "It comes to 160l. and the expenses will be enormous"—he suggested 50l. and I persuaded Bergman to take that and not prosecute, provided the solicitor would agree to it—I had employed Messrs. Huckley and Washington before the warrant was taken out—I said "I cannot go and liberate Mr. Pfeiffer, I cannot see how it can be done without solicitors, go and see your solicitor and take him to see Mr. Pfeiffer, and I shall go and see Pfeiffer and let you know"—I said that I was going to Nottingham, and he gave me a piece of paper stating where he would meet me and give me an answer—he came at the appointed time at the railway, station and said that the solicitor advised him not to do it—I had not known Kipps before.
Cross-examined. As a matter of fact 200l. was the sum to be paid, and I expected Bergman to accept it, subject to the approval of the Court—I took Bergman to Messrs. Huckley and Washington.

CHARLES STEVENS (Detective Officer P). I took the prisoner in Cromer Road, Peckham, on a warrant—I said "I shall take you in custody for defrauding Mr. Bergman of certain notes"—he said "Yes, I had the money, I gave him a receipt"—I said "There is a warrant for conspiracy as well as fraud"—he said that there was no one with him, he himself was the merchant and he should let him have the skins when they were ready—I have tried to find Stanislas, and have circulated his name in the "Police Gazette."

Cross-examined. The warrant was for conspiracy with another man un
known.

ANTONE KEWICSESKI (through an interpreter). I am the prisoner's father-in-law—I live with him and my daughter at 43, Clifton Crescent, Peckham—my wife lives with us—on 9th August the prisoner was ill—the prosecutor came between noon and 1 o'clock, and remained till about 4 o'clock—no other man came into the house while he was there—when he left my daughter the prisoner's wife went with him—the prisoner did not go out, because he was not well, he did not leave the house—Mrs. Pfeiffer came back after midnight.

Cross-examined by MR. CROOME. There are six rooms in the house—I was not in the same room with the prisoner and Bergman—they were in the front parlour and I was in the basement underneath, with my wife—I did not go out all day, nor did the prisoner—I saw Bergman leave—a Mr. David came at 4 o'clock.
Re-examined. There is a little garden in front of the house, and I can see everybody who comes up the path.

DAVID MORRIS . I am manager to a tailor, and live at 4, Commercial Road, Bermondsey—on 9th August, I went to the prisoner's house about 6.30 p.m., and stayed with him three-quarters of an hour—he was in bed—it is not true that he was at Charing Cross between 6 and 7 o'clock.

Cross-examined. I have known the prisoner about two years, and frequently go there in the evening—I was first asked to come and give evidence when I received a letter dated September 14th—nothing passed on the 9th to make me remember the date—I saw Mr. Kewickeski there—I do not know whether Mrs. Pfeiffer was at home.
JAMOLI LORENZO . I am a waiter at Gatti's Restaurant, Adelaide Street, Strand—on 9th August, about 7 p.m., I saw Mrs. Pfeiffer, Mr. Bergman,
and a little boy there—they left about 7.30, or 7.35 at the latest—they had something to eat there.

Cross-examined. I knew Mrs. Pfeiffer, she often came there—I was first spoken to about two weeks ago about giving evidence—there are a great many people at Gatti's in the course of a day—I had never seen them together before—when they asked me I remembered seeing them—they had some chops.

EMMA TAYLOR . I live at 36, Mark's Road, and am employed at the South Eastern Railway Station—it is part of my duty to clean out the waiting-room—I was there early one morning, just about the time the Paris mail starts—I do not know the day of the month—I saw the prisoner and prosecutor about 7 o'clock, or a little after, in the general waiting-room—they called for pen and ink, which I gave them, and left it with them—I did not see whether anything was written—I am prepared to swear that it was before 10 a. m.

Cross-examined. I had never seen Pfeiffer before—I saw him next in Horsemonger Lane about three weeks ago—the solicitor spoke to me about seeing him—it is not uncommon for pen and ink to be called for—I was very busy—a gentleman came and asked me if I remembered seeing a gentleman on this morning there, and then I remembered it.

Re-examined. I picked out the prisoner at Horsemonger Lane from ten or twelve others—I do not remain there all day, I generally leave about 10 o'clock, when my work is done—I am not there of an evening, I am only a charwoman.

EDWARD KIPPS . I am a tanner, of 94, Bermondsey—I have known the prisoner six or seven years; he is a respectable, trustworthy man—I have had transactions with him in selling skins for shoe manufacture—he was in my employ six years ago, and afterwards set up as a leather dresser—I do not know whether he is able to carry out contracts for the purchase of skins—I have done business with him within two years, and have a bill of his running now, and should be willing to have another, I have so much confidence in his honesty—to my surprise one day, Mrs. Pfeiffer called on me to say that her husband was in trouble, for conspiracy and fraud; would I be bail for him, and she called again on 25th August and asked me if I would refund the money for him—on 25th August Mr. Woolf and Mr. Bergman called and Mr. Woolf asked me if I would pay the money for him—I said not unless I knew the facts of the case first—he said that Mr. Pfeiffer had had the money to execute a contract, and had failed to do so, and they could neither get the goods nor the money—I asked what was the amount, he said 160l. and 80l. expenses—I said it was exhorbitant to expect 80l., and they reduced it to 40l.—I placed that on paper, but previously to that I said that it would be wrong for me to compromise the matter, the best way would be to ask the solicitor's opinion—I afterwards met the prisoner at the station for Nottingham, and told him I could not do it.

Cross-examined. He left me two or three years ago, but I did not lose sight of him—he frequently called and bought goods—I do not know whether he was carrying on business at the time he was taken—I did not give Woolf a bill for 200l.; I made no proposition, the proposition came from him—I have been outside the Court while this case has been proceeding—I have had a very few words of conversation about the matter—somebody came out and told me to go away from the place, but said nothing with regard to the evidence I was to give, except that I was to hold myself

in readiness, and that he was pleased I had come here—I bad not a lengthened conversation with the solicitor's clerk; there is no truth in it—I was to give the bill for 200l., and they would accept it, that was to be a settlement of the claim.
