Re-examined. It is not true that anyone suggested to me a word of the evidence which I have given.
ADOLPH DE GALLOW . I am clerk to Messrs. Parker and Bordman—I did not go outside the Court and communicate with the last witness—none of these witnesses were examined before the Magistrate.

GUILTY —
Twelve Months' Imprisonment.

749.
ROSETTA SKINNER (60), was indicted
for a libel on
Elizabeth Mary Ann Cleveland.

THOMAS JOHN DAVIS (Postman 478 S.W.) I deliver letters at the house of Mr. Cleveland, 78, Lothian Road—on 9th August this post-card (produced) was given to me by another postman, it was marked by him "No answer" on the same evening—I took it to the house where they had tried to deliver it the next morning at about 8.40 and delivered it to Miss Cleveland; it bears the mark of the Stockwell office; it would be collected from that part; and taken to the Stockwell office.
ELIZABETH MARY ANN CLEVELAND . I live at 78, Lothian Road, and am the prosecutrix's daughter—on 10th August I received this post-card and handed it to my father.

Cross-examined. I have known the defendant since Easter Monday—I have been on pretty good terms with her; we have not been friendly lately when we have met; I had a little disagreement with her—I have not a very good feeling towards her—we had no very serious quarrel—I know Jeannette Watson—I do net knew a young man named Sindy Scott—I am not engaged—the first time I saw Jeannette Watson was at Lambeth police-court; I know nothing about her.
Re-examined. The defendant was staying in our house, and my father gave her notice to leave.
ALFRED CLEVELAND . I live at 78, Lothian Road, Camberwell—on 10th August my daughter gave me this post-card—I do not know the writing—I made inquiries.

JEANNETTE WATSON . I live at 14, Treherne Road, North Brixton—the defendant was in the habit of coming to our house from time to time—I re
member her coming about 9th August when she asked me to write a post-card—the post-card produced I wrote at her dictation; she took it to the t—I did not write it out of my own head—I do not know anything about Miss Cleveland.

Cross-examined. I wrote it on 9th August. (Read: "I suppose you know your daughter is in the family-way. I should be careful. She will not destroy this as she did the other. I shall tell the Sisters of Mercy about it. She pretends now she is ill because she wants to destroy this. I also acquaint the police in case of accident") I mean to say that I wrote that card against a woman that I knew nothing about at the defendant's request—I have known her very long—I lent myself to write that against a woman who might be perfectly innocent—as far as I knew, what I was called upon to

write might have been an absolute falsehood, yet I wrote it and said nothing about it to the defendant at the time—I received a witness' summons to attend the police-court—I know Sindy Scott, they live in our house; I do not bow that he has been paying attention to Miss Cleveland; I will not undertake to swear that he has not—I did not say "I must say it was Mrs. Skinner now, or I shall be in for it myself; "I will undertake to say I never said those words—I first gave information of the defendant at Lambeth police-court—I don't know how long ago the post-card was received—I mean to say that having written that libellous post-card of a woman of whom I knew nothing that I remained all that time without communicating the fact to any Hiring human being—I do not know that I should have been implicated myself if I had not said it was Mrs. Skinner—Sindy Scott is not here to-day—I am still living at 14, Treherne Road—I am not in service at Tooting—lam living with my mother—I was living at 14, Treherne Road when the postcard was written—I am sure it was on the 9th she asked me to write it—I did not think at all about it—I never mentioned it to anybody between 9th August and 7th September—I did not tell Miss Cleveland that the defendant sent that post-card—I do not think they knew my writing—I did not know at that time that inquiries were being made as to the authorship of the post-card—I had not charged the defendant before that with having written it—I had not told her I should give information against her to screen my
self—I told her I should be put on my oath and should speak the truth.

ALFRED CLEVELAND (re-examined). I instituted inquiries, and I had some handwriting and compared it with the post-card and came to the conclusion that it was written by Miss Watson—I went to the house to acquaint the girl Watson with it first, and I was ushered in a room where the defendant was, and as soon as the girl came into the room Mrs. Skinner said "You know nothing at all about it," and she pushed the girl out of the room—my daughter is a single woman.

MART ANN GLYNN . I lived at 14, Treherne Road, North Brixton, when the post-card was written—I have known the defendant a little while; I remember her coming to 14, Treherne Road, into the parlour and asking Miss Watson who was there, to write a post-card—she said "Would you write this post-card?"—I did not see it written—I went out and came back and noticed writing on the card—the defendant had it then—the post-card produced is it.

Cross-examined. I heard the defendant ask Jeannette Watson to write it, and I saw it in her hand afterwards—the defendant cannot write—Mr. Charles Hamport lives in the same house with us on the second floor—we have changed our address now—I don't do anything; I am staying with my friends—I am a friend of Jeannette Watson's—I don't know when the post-card was written—I know Miss Watson wrote it; I did not know Miss Cleveland, I know a man named Sindy Scott, I know the whole family—I have known the defendant for two or three months—we have been on pretty good terms—I knew Miss Watson had written the post-card, but I could not say the exact one.

By THE COURT. This is it—she wrote a post-card to Miss Cleveland—I did not see her write it; this is her writing—I did not know what she had written—I do not remember the date, but 1 remember the defendant asking Miss Watson to write to Miss Cleveland, and I saw the defendant go away with the post-card afterwards.
WILLIAM NEWBAT (Policeman L 24). I personally served a copy of a
summons on the defendant for libel, in the Lambeth police-court—she was there—was said "All right, I will attend to it—I know Orchard Row, it is between 300 or 400 yards from the Treherne Road.

ARTHUR JOHNSON . I live at 14, Treherne Road, Brixton, and am the defendant's grandson; I live with her—I remember her being ill about the beginning of August—I was called at the police-court and gave evidence that she was ill on Sunday, Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday, Thursday, and Friday—Sunday was the 5th, so Friday would be 10th—she was confined to her bed; I was in and out of the room during the day—she did not get up—our place of abode then was 1, Orchard Row, Camberwell New Road—14, Treherne Road is five minutes' walk from Orchard Row—she was very ill.

Cross-examined. I am twelve years old—I have always been quite sure that Sunday was 5th August—I did not say at the Lambeth police-court my grandmother was taken ill about Tuesday, 5th August—my grandmother visited 14, Treherne Road, before she went to live there—I saw Miss Watson write once before for my grandmother to a Mr. Sharland, our broker—I remember the Sunday, Monday, Tuesday Wednesday, Thursday, and Friday, because we moved into Orchard Row on Saturday, the 4th—I have had no conversation with my grandmother as to the evidence I should give—she never reminded me that she was ill at that time—we have talked about her being locked up—she told me to come up.

Re-examined. We were at Orchard Row about three weeks, and moved in on the Saturday—the day after my grandmother was taken ill, and she remained there up to Friday in the following week—I gave this evidence at the police-court—my grandmother told me It was the 5th August.
By THE COURT. I go to school between 9 o'clock and 9.30—I did not go to school on the days in question, because we had just moved in and we could not find a school.
MATILDA HARBISON . I am a married women and live at 1, Orchard Row—I remember going to the defendant on 4th. August; she had just moved in to 1, Orchard Row—I did not see her when she was ill in bed.

ADELAIDE SILCOCK . I live at Victoria Road, Peckham, the defendant is my aunt—I remember visiting her at 1, Orchard Row, on 8th and 9th August—I found her bad a-bed, she appeared to be very ill and unable to get up—she said she had been in great pain since Sunday night—I do not know anything of Mary Ann Glyun—I have never written letters, for my aunt; I can write—Arthur Johnson is a good scholar.
Cross-examined. I was not with my aunt all day on 8th August, but I was on the 9 th—I remember the days so well because bank-holiday was on the 6th—it was a slack week, that makes me remember it.

----COOMBES. I live at 14, Treherne Road, Brixton, the defendant is my mother, I support her—she lives at home with me—at the time she moved to Orchard Row I saw her in bed—she told me she was suffering from nature, she was confined to her bed from Sunday night till the following Friday—she was taken bad the next night after we moved.

By THE COURT. She was up on the Friday when I came home—I am a chemist's assistant—I have written letters for her several times on ordinary business transactions—we did live in the house along with Miss Cleveland—Orchard Row is about a quarter of an hour's walk from Treherne Road.
Cross-examined. We lived at the Cleveland Road, and for some reason we
left—when I walk from Treherne Road to Camberwell Road Station, it takes me a good ten minutes to catch the train of a morning.
Re-examined. The defendant appeared to be ill—we gave notice to leave because the place was not big enough—there has been no misunderstanding between my mother and Miss Cleveland that I know of.

THOMAS JOHN DAVIS (re-examined). I remember seeing the defendant between 6th and 10th August outside Mr. Holyhead's shop, and she asked me if I would be kind enough to re-direct all letters from Orchard Row to 14, Treherne Road, as she had removed to Mrs. Watson's house in the name of Harris or Harrison, and I told her to write to the post-master, I could not do it—I fix the date by its being a day or two after bank-holiday—she seemed as well as ever.

Cross-examined. I never gave this evidence before, either at the police-court or here to-day—I am certain it was not on the 3rd or the 11th, that I met her—it was previously to my delivering the post-card—this was not suggested to me after I heard Mr. Coombes' evidence, I volunteered it—I was called to prove the delay of the post-card.

p.rs: GUILTY— Recommended to mercy by the Jury—

div1.p: ADJOURNED TO MONDAY, OCTOBER 22ND, 1877.
